image.altText: Electoral commission campaign, woman grins and signals number '7'. Text reads '7 or more to make your vote count'

props.synopsis: This year's state election returned a near-record rise in the number of votes that couldn't be counted, with some voters when numbering from one to seven on the ballot doubling or omitting a six or doubling or omitting a seven.

title.children: Tasmanian voters confused when numbering from 1 to 7, with double ups of 6 in state election count

image.altText: A couple outside their home in western Sydney.

props.synopsis: It was supposed to be the end of the "property cyclone", but more builders are going under, new home builds are declining and consumers are left fighting to fix defects in newly constructed houses and apartments.

title.children: 'When the cash flow stops, they go bust': More builders are collapsing and consumers are fighting to fix their homes

image.altText: crowd on field final waverley park getty edit

props.synopsis: It was supposed to be one of the world's biggest stadiums, now all that remains of Waverley Park is the shell of a stand. And with a fight on its hands over Hobart's AFL stadium, what has the league learnt from its most ambitious build?

title.children: AFL has its sights on a Hobart stadium, but some say the league should learn from the mistakes of Waverley Park

image.altText: A weather map showing heavy rain forecast over eastern Australia.

props.synopsis: Sydney is on flood watch alongside at least 30 rivers across NSW and Queensland as torrential rain is expected to pummel eastern Australia over the next 48 hours.

title.children: Eastern Australia to be hit with major rain event, parts of Queensland and NSW on flood watch

image.altText: Jose Andres.

props.synopsis: Jose Andres says an attack that killed seven humanitarian aid workers in Gaza targeted them "systematically, car by car".

title.children: World Central Kitchen founder says Israel targeted his aid workers 'systematically, car by car'

image.altText: A woman in a World Central Kitchen shirt smiles at the camera standing in a cafe

props.synopsis: There have been "tipping points" since the war in Gaza began nearly six months ago. But this week's deadly Israeli air strike on an aid convoy may prove to be one of the most significant — and on one side of Australian politics, the response has been fury.

title.children: As Albanese tips into outrage over the death of an Australian aid worker in an Israeli air strike, Dutton remains unmoved

image.altText: A woman in a blue dress sitting in a wheelchair in her home.

props.synopsis: Qantas has been slammed over its treatment of a woman with disability who was trying to get from Perth to Canberra for a work trip.

title.children: 'Unacceptable and appalling': Qantas charged Anwen $6.4k for business seats because economy wasn't accessible

image.altText: Australian Tax Office

props.synopsis: Small business owners have collected billions of dollars in GST from their customers in recent years but failed to hand it to the tax office, prompting a warning from the new tax commissioner.

title.children: Has the GST you've paid actually gone to the government? The billions owed to the ATO suggests a lot hasn't

image.altText: A close up of a copper and plastic IUD.

props.synopsis: Women's health specialists say gender bias in rebates for medical procedures is costing women more money and disincentivising women's health practitioners.

title.children: Is Medicare biased against women? These doctors and midwives think so

image.altText: A close up of a woman holding a fringe bag wearing an orange shawl and pants.

props.synopsis: Australians in Bali for holidays have been left confused by a new $15 tourism tax and efforts by police to enforce payment.

title.children: Fed up with badly behaved tourists and obnoxious influencers, Bali has a new tax and a new list of rules

image.altText: A sparse, concrete warehouse with a few shelves, and a forklift.

props.synopsis: Beebird Logistics has provided a direct mail service between Australia and China for years. However, the company is currently plagued by months-long delays, with parcels missing for almost half a year.

title.children: When a courier company vanished, all signs pointed to one address. But what the ABC found was an empty warehouse

image.altText: A woman in a blue dress, Brittany Higgins, walks surrounded by other people.

props.synopsis: An attempt at peace talks to avert a costly defamation trial brought by Liberal senator Linda Reynolds against former staffer Brittany Higgins fail after Ms Higgins allegedly again took to social media to critique her former employer.

title.children: Mediation talks collapse between Linda Reynolds, Brittany Higgins with defamation trial now set to proceed

image.altText: A young man with dark hair, a beard, a suit and glasses walks on the street.

props.synopsis: Television news and current affairs in Australia has traditionally been a competitive pursuit, so it's no surprise that two television networks have been caught up in the response to one of the most notorious criminal allegations in recent Australian history.

title.children: Two major news networks now embroiled in Bruce Lehrmann's defamation action

image.altText: Yolande dressed as Cleop[atra with a group of people in fancy dress

props.synopsis: An ABC investigation has uncovered the details in material promoting Mr Entsch's wife Yolonde as the LNP candidate for the state seat of Cairns.

title.children: Federal MP 'delivered' multi-million-dollar contract to company that hired his wife to run 'character building' craft workshops

image.altText: Alice voxxie thumbnail

props.synopsis: As the two-week youth curfew in Alice Springs hits the halfway point, here's what locals think about the measure.

title.children: One week into a youth curfew, what do Alice Springs locals think?

image.altText: Against a white background a hand holds a smartphone by thumb and index finger, hanging from up high.

props.synopsis: Finding it hard to stop scrolling? These experts recommend simple changes to the way you use your smartphone to cultivate a healthier relationship with it.

title.children: Why this expert is 'calling bulls**t' on claims we're addicted to our phones

image.altText: Three macaques climb on a couple trying to take a selfie, with one monkey covering the eyes of the woman

props.synopsis: Local officials have announced a plan to rein in the population of macaques — who are a cultural symbol and tourist attraction — after encounters left visitors battered and bruised.

title.children: No more monkey business — Thai city of Lopburi wages war on monkey mayhem

image.altText: Girl e-learning with headphones

props.synopsis: Kids are increasingly wearing headphones and earbuds but the noise they're exposed to could be damaging their hearing, experts warn. So here's what you can do to help prevent that.

title.children: Is your child listening safely? How to protect young ears from too much headphone noise

image.altText: Two people, a man and a woman, sit in an ornate room

props.synopsis: Scoop promises to tell the story of the days leading up to the interview that all but ruined Prince Andrew's reputation.

title.children: The true story behind Scoop, a new movie about Prince Andrew's catastrophic BBC interview

image.altText: Large native forest tree being trucked on a rural road.

props.synopsis: Tasmania is home to the world's tallest flowering trees, but many have been at risk of logging. The definition of a 'giant' tree that gets protection has now changed to include more of them — but not everyone is convinced.

title.children: Thousands of Tasmania's 'giant' native trees could now be spared from logging

image.altText: A gun made from pipe parts and nuts and bolts.

props.synopsis: Police officers on patrol arrested the 19-year-old man in Hobart's CBD after an alleged theft from a business, and found him with a loaded homemade gun.

title.children: Teen arrested in Hobart CBD with loaded pipe gun and ammunition

image.altText: Slices of body parts covered in Perspex and put on display on walls.

props.synopsis: It is unclear if family members knew or consented to body parts from their loved ones going on display in a Hobart university museum following coronial autopsies, the Coroner's Office says.

title.children: Body parts from coronial autopsies may have been put on display in Hobart museum without family consent

image.altText: A couple posing in front of their coffee caravan business.

props.synopsis: For years, Arun Subba has been immersed in coffee. But after more than 14 years working as someone else's barista, he decided it was time to hit the road and become his own boss.

title.children: Why these Melbourne coffee businesses are swapping shopfronts for mobile vans

image.altText: Gather Round

props.synopsis: The football begins tonight night when the Crows take on Melbourne, with Adelaide desperate for its first win.

title.children: 'It brings an energy, it brings an enthusiasm': Adelaide buzzing as AFL Gather Round kicks off with more than 200,000 tickets sold

image.altText: Two women look at a share price board outside the ASX in Sydney.

props.synopsis: A small gain on Wall Street is likely to send Australian stocks higher, while US Federal Reserve chair Jerome Powell reaffirmed the need for more debate and data before interest rates cuts. Follow the latest updates in our live blog.

title.children: ASX to rise, Wall Street little changed on unclear rate cut timing

liveBlogKeyEvents.title: New tax commissioner says small businesses are failing to pass on collectable debt
Seven in reputational damage as fallout mounts from Bruce Lehrmann allegations

image.altText: Bruce Lehrmann walking into court.

props.synopsis: A former Seven Network producer claims the broadcaster paid for "illicit drugs and prostitutes" as part of its efforts to secure an exclusive sit-down interview with Bruce Lehrmann.

title.children: Federal Court publishes affidavit detailing Seven Network payments to Bruce Lehrmann, including for sex, drugs

image.altText: People huddle in grief near candles which have been lit and placed on the ground

props.synopsis: The 12-year-old fatally shot a classmate and wounded two others in the attack that has prompted a national day of mourning in Finland.

title.children: Student suspected of fatal Finland school shooting a victim of bullying, police say

image.altText: Pepole in protective clothing stand in the remains of a partially collapsed building.

props.synopsis: Japan and the Philippines lift all their tsunami warnings and advisories after an earthquake with a preliminary magnitude of 7.5 struck near Taiwan.

title.children: Nine people dead after powerful earthquake hits Taiwan, more than 900 others injured

image.altText: A photo of a woman wearing a black long sleeve shirt, holding a glass of water with a plate of food in front of her.

props.synopsis: This year, Muslims and non-Muslims alike are fasting for a variety of reasons, from showing their solidarity and empathy with Palestinians fasting in Gaza to celebrating their own religious celebrations.

title.children: How the famine in Gaza sparked worldwide fasting among non-Muslims in solidarity with Palestinians

image.altText: A woman smiles with mountains behind her.

props.synopsis: The grieving family of a Palestinian aid worker killed in Israeli drone strikes say they loved Australian woman Zomi Frankcom, who was also killed.

title.children: Australian aid worker Zomi Frankcom was 'an absolute ray of sunshine'

image.altText: GGNEW

props.synopsis: Samantha Mostyn has a very different CV compared to the previous 10 governors-general.

title.children: Samantha Mostyn will be the second woman to become governor-general, but she is a first in other respects

image.altText: Gurjinder Singh with his arm around Dharmvir Singh.

props.synopsis: The family of Dharmvir and Gurjinder Singh, who drowned on Easter Sunday in a hotel pool, say words cannot explain their gratitude for the community support they have received as they come to terms with their loss.

title.children: Gold Coast double drowning victims remembered as 'two of the nicest people in the world' by family

image.altText: Close up of cracked earth

props.synopsis: Australian research shows naturally occurring megadroughts will be more severe and last longer due to climate change.

title.children: Scientists warn Australians to prepare for megadroughts that last more than 20 years

image.altText: A rusted pipe pushes out hot water into a small pond

props.synopsis: There are fears that injecting liquefied CO2 into a freshwater reservoir that underlies almost a quarter of the continent could contaminate the water supply for more than 180,000 people.

title.children: More than 100 towns rely on this outback freshwater source – but what if it was contaminated?

image.altText: A young woman sits on a horse, which is tethered to another horse, while a dog plays on the tideline at a beach.

props.synopsis: A trained lifesaver leapt off her horse to assist the trio on Easter Sunday when they became caught in a rip at a notorious Victorian beach.

title.children: 'Kept asking me if they were going to die': Heroic horserider details dramatic rescue of drowning dad and daughters
